title: Welcome
text:
Welcome! üßô
This presentation, ‚ÄúReproducible Research: Every little helps‚Äù, offers a brief overview of key ideas and insights I‚Äôve gathered from the literature‚Äîalong with a few lessons I‚Äôve learned along the way that may aid some of you.

title: Welcome
text:
Background of the presentation
This presentation was designed for a weekly seminar series at the LEHNA laboratory. It originated from discussions with my friend and lab member J√©r√©my Bacon. This seminar is a shorter, less hands-on version of the workshop I conducted in February of this year‚Äîyou can explore the full materials and site here.
Recognising the ongoing need to share knowledge about reproducible research, I decided to organise this session to contribute what I know on the topic (or what I think I know üëΩ). While I don‚Äôt claim to be an expert, every little helps. My hope is that this seminar sparks enough interest to encourage others to explore and strive toward more reproducible, transparent, and accessible research practices.

title: Welcome
text:
Description
The presentation focuses on introducing the what, where, when, and how of reproducible research. We‚Äôll explore the benefits of working reproducibly‚Äîboth for others and for ourselves‚Äîexamine the factors that limit or discourage reproducible practices, and discuss practical, incremental solutions for becoming more reproducible in our work. A seminar on this subject gains value through interaction and engagement from the audience, so I‚Äôve woven discussion questions throughout the presentation to encourage exchange and reflection.

title: Welcome
text:
Inspiration
The presentation‚Äôs structure and certain content elements were inspired by:

the Reproducible research presentation from the Data Toolbox for Reproducible Research in Ecology organized by the FRB-CESAB and the GdR EcoStat
Alston JM, Rick JA. 2021 A beginner‚Äôs guide to conducting reproducible research. Bull. Ecol. Soc. Am. 102, 1‚Äì14. (doi:10.1002/bes2.1801c)
the Introduction to Reproducibility presentation created by Repro4Everyone

Gundersen Odd Erik 2021 The fundamental principles of reproducibility Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A.37920200210 DOI:¬†10.1098/rsta.2020.0210.

title: Reproducible Research
text:
What does reproducibility mean actually?



Direct reproducibility (also called experimental reproducibility) üß™




Analytical reproducibility (also called computational reproducibility) üíª




Other related terms to distinguish:



Replicability: Different data | Same analysis methods
Robustness: Same data | Different analysis methods
Generalisability: Different data | Different analysis methods






Schloss, 2018. DOI: 10.1128/mbio.00525-18


The Turing Way Community, Becky Arnold, Louise Bowler, Sarah Gibson, Patricia Herterich, Rosie Higman, ‚Ä¶ Kirstie Whitaker. (2019, March 25). The Turing Way: A Handbook for Reproducible Data Science (Version v0.0.4). Zenodo. 10.5281/zenodo.3233986

Reproducible Research

title: Reproducible Research
section: Why are we talking about this now?
text:
Why are we talking about this now?










Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452‚Äì454 (2016). DOI: 10.1038/533452a.






70% of researchers can‚Äôt reproduce others‚Äô findings
60% can‚Äôt reproduce their own findings
Non-reproducible biomedical research costs $28 billion/year(Freedman et al.¬†2015)

title: Reproducible Research
section: How important is it? Well, quite important
text:
How important is it? Well, quite important
 



Anyone (with a similar level of skills) should be able to do reproduce your research and benefit from it
Funders (e.g., ANR) and journals now require data and code accessibility, which aligns with the growing open-science movement
If I keep my data and code, I have a competitive advantage
If I share my data and code, my work will gain more visibility (and citations üòé)

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Advantages
 


It obliges you to verify your work (by sharing both docs, data and code)
Your future self will thank you (you‚Äôll be much more productive)
Your collaborators too
By ensuring reproducibility, you reinforce your credibility and reputation
Employers increasingly value reproducible research skills
Reproducibility fosters trust in scientific progress and accelerates it

title: Reproducible Research
section: What factors do you think can limit reproducibility? ü§î
text: What factors do you think can limit reproducibility? ü§î

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Factors limiting reproducibility


  

Failures of reproducibility cannot be traced to a single cause
Nearly every aspect of a study needs to be considered‚Äì from conception to publication









Baker, M. 1,500 scientists lift the lid on reproducibility. Nature 533, 452‚Äì454 (2016). DOI: 10.1038/533452a.

text:

During data analysis 
Best coding practices

title: Reproducible Research
text:
During data analysis 
Best coding practices


Issues: Without proper coding practices, analyses become error-prone, impossible to reproduce, and difficult for others (including your future self) to understand or verify

title: Reproducible Research
text:
During data analysis 
Best coding practices


Issues: Without proper coding practices, analyses become error-prone, impossible to reproduce, and difficult for others (including your future self) to understand or verify




Solutions:

Use reproducible environments




e.g. renv R package for project-specific R environments




Ushey K, Wickham H (2025). renv: Project Environments. R package version 1.1.5, https://rstudio.github.io/renv/.

title: Reproducible Research
text:
During data analysis 
Best coding practices


Issues: Without proper coding practices, analyses become error-prone, impossible to reproduce, and difficult for others (including your future self) to understand or verify




Solutions:

Use reproducible environments
Document your code



# penguin_analysis.R
# Author: Your Name
# Purpose: Summarise bill length across species in `palmerpenguins` dataset
# Date: 2025-09-22

# ---- Load packages ----
library(dplyr)
library(palmerpenguins)

# ---- Summarise bill length by species ----
bill_length_summary_df <- penguins |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(mean_bill_length_mm = mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE))

Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Reproducible Research
text:
During data analysis 
Best coding practices


Issues: Without proper coding practices, analyses become error-prone, impossible to reproduce, and difficult for others (including your future self) to understand or verify




Solutions:

Use reproducible environments
Document your code
Harmonise your code style



# Variable name is way too descriptive
mean_of_penguins_bill_length_in_millimeters_for_all_islands <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

# Variable name too cryptic
x <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

# A better option
bill_length_mean_mm <- mean(penguins$bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

Finalising results and sharing

title: Reproducible Research
text:
After data analysis 
Finalising results and sharing


Issues: Research becomes inaccessible and irreproducible when results are manually created, data is poorly archived, and materials are trapped behind paywalls or on unstable platforms

title: Reproducible Research
text:

Issues: Research becomes inaccessible and irreproducible when results are manually created, data is poorly archived, and materials are trapped behind paywalls or on unstable platforms

Produce figures + tables with code(not by üëã)

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Take-home messages


Reproducible research is a process, not a destination




Start small: pick one practice and build habits
Perfect is the enemy of good
The goal: better collaboration, scientific rigor, and trust in science
To advance, we must code a little‚Ä¶









Artwork by Allison Horst
